column1: 22:00|"ten o'clock that night"|"What happened next has become part of historical legend
column2: a tale told to every American schoolchild. At ten o'clock that night
column3: Warren and Revere met. They decided they had to warn the communities surrounding Boston that the British were on their way
column4: so that local militia could be roused to meet them. Revere was spirited across Boston Harbor to the ferry landing at Charlestown. He jumped on a horse and began his “midnight ride” to Lexington. In two hours
column5: he covered thirteen miles. In every town he passed through along the way — Charlestown
column8: Menotomy — he knocked on doors and spread the word
column9: telling local colonial leaders of the oncoming British
column10: and telling them to spread the word to others. Church hells started ringing. Drums started beating. The news spread like a virus as those informed by Paul Revere sent out riders of their own
column11: until alarms were going off throughout the entire region. The word was in Lincoln
column18: and by nine in the morning had reached as far west as Ashby
column19: near Worcester. When the British finally began their march toward Lexington on the morning of the nineteenth
column20: their foray into the countryside was met — to their utter astonishment— with organized and fierce resistance. In Concord that day
column21: the British were confronted and soundly beaten by the colonial militia
column22: and from that exchange came the war known as the American Revolution."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column1: ap ~ 02:50|"around 250"|"All of us know someone like this. But I don't think that we spend a lot of time thinking about the importance of these kinds of people. I'm not even sure that most of us really believe that the kind of person who knows everyone really knows everyone. But they do. There is a simple way to show this. In the paragraph below is a list of around 250 surnames
column2: all taken at random from the Manhattan phone book. Go down the list and give yourself a point every time you see a surname that is shared by someone you know. (The definition of “know” here is very broad. For example
column3: if you sat down next to that person on a train
column4: you would know their name if they introduced themselves to you and they would know your name.) Multiple names count. If the name is Johnson
column7: you get three points. The idea is that your score on this test should roughly represent how social you are. It's a simple way of estimating how many friends and acquaintances you have."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column3: is the explanation for why Paul Revere's midnight ride started a word-of-mouth epidemic and William Dawes's ride did not. Paul Revere was the Roger Horchow or the Lois Weisberg of his day. He was a Connector. He was
column5: gregarious and intensely social. When he died
column7: in the words of one contemporary newspaper account
column8: by “troops of people.” He was a fisherman and a hunter
column10: a frequenter of pubs and a successful businessman. He was active in the local Masonic Lodge and was a member of several select social clubs. He was also a doer
column11: a man blessed — as David Hackett Fischer recounts in his brilliant book Paul Revere's Ride — with an “uncanny genius for being at the center of events.” Fischer writes: When Boston imported its first streetlights in 1774
column12: Paul Revere was asked to serve on the committee that made the arrangement. When the Boston market required regulation
column13: Paul Revere was appointed its clerk. After the Revolution
column15: he was chosen health officer of Boston
column16: and coroner of Suffolk County. When a major fire ravaged the old wooden town
column17: he helped to found the Massachusetts Mutual Fire Insurance Company
column18: and his name was first to appear on its charter of incorporation. As poverty became a growing problem in the new republic
column19: he called the meeting that organized the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association
column20: and was elected its first president. When the community of Boston was shattered by the most sensational murder trial of his generation
column21: Paul Revere was chosen foreman of the jury."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"This is surely part of the explanation for why Paul Revere's message was so powerful on the night of his midnight ride. News of the British march did not come by fax
column2: or by means of a group e-mail. It wasn't broadcast on the nightly news
column3: surrounded by commercials. It was carried by a man
column5: riding on a cold night with no personal agenda other than a concern for the liberty of his peers. With Hush Puppies as well
column6: perhaps the shoes caught the attention of Connectors precisely because they weren't part of any self-conscious
column7: commercial fashion trend. Maybe a fashion Maven went to the East Village
column9: and found out that you could get these really cool old Hush Puppies at a certain thrift store
column12: who bought the shoes for themselves because there is something about the personal
column14: expert opinion of a Maven that makes us all sit up and listen. And why are the Zagat restaurant guides so popular? Partly it is because they are a convenient guide to all the restaurants in a given town."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"He's always revving up and gearing down. Sometimes when he is making an aside be will rev up even further
column2: as if to put in his own verbal parentheses. He asks lots of rhetorical questions. ""I love my job. I love my job. I'm a workaholic. I get here at six and seven in the morning. I get out at nine at night. I manage a lot of money. I'm one of the top producers in the nation. But I don't tell my clients that. I'm not here because of that. I'm here to help people."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Paul Revere started a word-of-mouth epidemic with the phrase “The British are coming.” It he had instead gone on that midnight ride to tell people he was having a sale on the pewter mugs at his silversmith shop
column3: with all his enormous personal gifts
column4: could not have galvanized the Massachusetts countryside."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column1: 02:00|"two in the morning"|"The purpose of the experiment was to try to find out why prisons are such nasty places. Was it because prisons are full of nasty people
column2: or was it because prisons are such nasty environments that they make people nasty? In the answer to that question is obviously the answer to the question posed by Bernie Goetz and the subway cleanup
column3: which is how much influence docs immediate environment have on the way people behave? What Zimbardo found out shocked him. The guards
column4: some of whom had previously identified themselves as pacifists
column5: fell quickly into the role of hard-bitten disciplinarians. The first night they woke up the prisoners at two in the morning and made them do pushups
column7: and perform other arbitrary tasks. On the morning of the second day
column8: the prisoners rebelled. They ripped off their numbers and barricaded themselves in their cells. The guards responded by stripping them
column10: and throwing the leader of the rebellion into solitary confinement. “There were times when we were pretty abusive
column11: getting right in their faces and yelling at them
column12: ” one guard remembers. “It was part of the whole atmosphere of terror.” As the experiment progressed
column13: the guards got systematically cruder and more sadistic. “What we were unprepared for was the intensity of the change and the speed at which it happened
column14: ” Ximbardo says. The guards were making the prisoners say to one another they loved each other
column15: and making them march down the hall-way
column17: with paper bags over their heads. “It was completely the opposite from the way I conduct myself now
column18: ” another guard remembers. ""I think I was positively creative in terms of my mental cruelty.'' After 36 hours
column19: one prisoner began to get hysterical
column20: and had to be released. Four more then had to be released because of “extreme emotional depression
column23: and acute-anxiety.” Zimbardo had originally intended to have the experiment run for two weeks. He called it off after six days. “I realize now
column24: ” one prisoner said after the experiment was over
column25: “that no matter how together I thought I was inside my head
column26: my prisoner behavior was often less under my control than I realized.” Another said: ""I began to feel that I was losing my identity
column28: the person who volunteered to get me into this prison (because it was a prison to me
column29: it still is a prison to me
column30: I don't regard it as an experiment or a simulation...) was distant from me
column32: until finally I wasn't that person. I was 416. I was really my number and 416 was really going to have to decide what to do."""|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"

column1: ap 01:00|one|"There is a concept in cognitive psychology called the channel capacity
column2: which refers to the amount of space in our brain for certain kinds of information. Suppose
column4: that I played you a number of different musical tones
column6: and asked you to identify each one with a number. If I played you a really low tone
column8: and if I played you a medium tone you would call it two
column9: and a high tone you would call three. The purpose of the test is to find out how long you can continue to distinguish among different tones. People with perfect pitch
column11: can play this game forever. You can play them dozens of tones
column12: and they'll be able to distinguish between all of them. But for the majority of us
column13: this game is much harder. Most people can divide tones into only about six different categories before they begin to make mistakes and start lumping different tones in the same category."|"The Tipping Point"|"Malcolm Gladwell"
